editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: A new way to pay old debts a comedy as it hath been often acted at the phoenix in drury-lane, by the Queen's majesty's servants.
London, printed by E. P. for Henry Seyle, dwelling in s. Paul's churchyard, at the sign of the tiger's head. Mdcxxiii. m. .

div.head: To the right honourable Robert Earl of Carnarvan, master falconer of England.
div.p:
Pardon I beseech you my boldness, in presuming to shelter this comedy under the wings of your lordship's favour, and protection, I am not ignorant (Having never yet deserved you in my service) that it cannot but meet with a severe construction, if in the clemency of your noble disposition, you fashion not a better defence for me, than I can fancy for myself. All I can allege is, that divers Italian
princes, and lords of eminent rank in England, have not disdained to receive, and read poems of this nature, nor am I wholly lost in my hopes, but that your honour (Who have ever expressed yourself a favourer, and friend to the Muses) may vouchsafe, in your gracious acceptance of this trifle, to give me encouragement, to present you with some laboured work, and of a higher strain hereafter, I was born a devoted servant, to the thrice noble family of your incomparable lady, and am most ambitious, but with a becoming distance, to be known to your lordship, which if you please to admit, I shall embrace it as a bounty, that while I live shall oblige me to acknowledge you for my noble patron, and profess myself to be

closer.signed: Your honour's true servant Philip Massinger.

div.head: To the ingenious author master Philip Massinger, on his comedy called, a new way to pay old debts.

lg.l: 'Tis a rare charity, and thou couldst not
So proper to the time have found a plot:
Yet whilst you teach to pay, you lend, the age
We wretches live in; that to come, the stage,
The thronged audience that was thither brought
Invited by your fame, and to be taught
This lesson. All are grown indebted more,
And when they look for freedom ran in score.
It was a cruel courtesy to call
In hope of liberty, and then, enthrall .
The nobles are your bondmen gentry, and
All besides those that did not understand.
They were no men of credit bankrupts born
Fit to be trusted with no stock, but scorn.
You have more wisely credited to such,
That though they cannot pay, can value much.
I am your debtor too, but to my shame
Repay you nothing back, but your own fame.
You may remember how you chid me when
I ranked you equal with those glorious men;
Beaumont, and Fletcher: if you love not praise
You must for bear the publishing of plays.
The crafty mazes of the cunning plot;
The polished phrase; the sweet expressions; got
Neither by theft, nor violence; the conceit
Fresh, and unsullied; all is of weight,
Able to make the captive reader know
I did but justice when I placed you so.
A shamefast blushing would become the brow
Of some weak virgin writer, we allow,
To you a kind of pride; and there where most,
Should blush at commendations, you should boast.
If any think I flatter, let him look
Of from my idle trifles on thy book.

list.head: Dramatis personae.
list.item: Alworth.a young gentleman page to lord Lovell.
Marrall.a team-driver. A creature of sir Giles Overreach.
Order. Amble. Furnace. Watchall.servants to the lady Alworth.

body.head: A new way to pay old debts: a comedy.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: No bouse? nor no tobacco?

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: Not a suck sir,
Nor the remainder of a single can
Left by a drunken porter, all night paled too.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: Not the dropping of the tap for your morning's draught, sir,
'Tis verity I assure you.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: Verity, you brach!
The devil turned precisian? Rogue what am I?

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: Troth durst I trust you with a looking glass,
To let you see your trim shape, you would quit me,
And take the name yourself.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: How! dog?

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: Even so, sir.
And I must tell you if you but advance,
Your plimworth cloak, you shall be soon instructed
There dwells, and within call, if it please your worship,
A potent monarch, called the constable,
That does command a citadel, called the stocks;
Whose guards are certain files of rusty billmen,
Such as with great dexterity will hale
Your tattered, lousy ---

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: Rascal, slave.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: No rage, sir.

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: At his own peril, do not put yourself
In too much heat, there being no water near
To quench your thirst, and sure for other liquor,
As mighty ale, or beer, they are things I take it
You must no more remember, not in a dream sir.

sp.speaker: Wellborne.
sp.l: Why thou unthankful villain dar'st thou talk thus?
Is not thy house, and all thou hast my gift?

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: I find it not in chalk, and Timothy Tapwell
Does keep no other register.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: Am not I he
Whose riots fed, and clothed thee? wert thou not
Born on my father's land, and proud to be
A drudge in his house?

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: What I was sir, it skills not,
What you are is apparent. Now for a farewell ;
Since you talk of father, in my hope it will torment you,
I'll briefly tell your story. Your dead father,
My quondam master, was a man of worship,
Old sir John Wellborne, justice of peace, and quorum,
And stood fair to be custos rotulorum;
Bore the whole sway of the shire; kept a great house;
Relieved the poor, and so forth; but he dying,
And the twelve hundred a year coming to you,
Late master Francis, but now forlorn Welborne.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: Slave, stop, or I shall lose myself.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: Very hardly;
You cannot out of your way.

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: But to my story.
You were then a lord of Akers; the prime gallant;
And I your underbutler; note the change now.
You had a merry time of't. Hawks, and hounds,
With choice of running horses; mistresses
Of all sorts, and all sizes; yet so hot
As their embraces made your lordships melt;
Which your uncle sir Giles Overreach observing,
Resolving not to lose a drop of 'em,
On foolish mortgages, statutes, and bonds,
For a while supplied your looseness, and then left you.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: Some curate hath penned this invective, mongrel,
And you have studied it.

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: I have not done yet:
Your land gone, and your credit not worth a token,
You grew the common borrower, no man scaped
Your paper-pellets, from the gentleman
To the beggars on high ways, that sold you switches
In your gallantry.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: I shall switch your brains out.

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: Where poor Tim Tapwell with a little stock
Some forty pounds or so, bought a small cottage,
Humbled myself to marriage with my Froth here;
Gave entertainment.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: Yes, to whores, and canters,
Clubbers by night.

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: True, but they brought in profit,
And had a gift to pay for what they called for,
And stuck not like your mastership. The poor income
I gleaned from them, hath made me in my parish,
Thought worthy to be scavenger, and in time
May rise to be overseer of the poor;
Which if I do, on your petition Welborne,
I may allow you thirteen pence a quarter,
And you shall thank my worship.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: Thus you dogbolt,
And thus.

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: Cry out for help.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: Stir and thou diest:
Your potent prince the constable shall not save you.
Hear me ungrateful hellhound; did not I
Make purses for you? Then you licked my boots,
And thought your holy day cloak too course to clean 'em.
'Twas I that when I heard thee swear, if ever
Thou couldst arrive at forty pounds, thou wouldst
Live like an emperor: 'twas I that gave it,
In ready gold. Deny this, wretch.

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: I must sir,
For from the tavern to the taphouse, all
On forfeiture of their licences stand bound,
Never to remember who their best guests were,
If they grew poor like you.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: They are well rewarded
That beggar themselves to make such cuckolds rich.
Thou viper thankless viper; impudent bawd!
But since you are grown forgetful, I will help
Your memory, and tread thee into mortar:
Not leave one bone unbroken.

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: Ask mercy.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: I will not be granted.

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: Hold, for my sake hold.
Deny me, Frank? they are not worth your anger.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: For once thou hast redeemed them from this sceptre:

lg.l: But let 'em vanish, creeping on their knees,
And if they grumble, I revoke my pardon.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: This comes of your prating husband, you presumed
On your ambling wit, and must use your glib tongue
Though you are beaten lame for't.

sp.speaker: Tapwell.
sp.l: Patience Froth.
There's law to cure our bruises.
sp.stage: They go off on their hands, and knees.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: Sent to your mother?

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: My lady, Frank, my patroness! my all!
She's such a mourner for my father's death,
And in her love to him, so favours me,
That I cannot pay too much observance to her.
There are few such stepdames.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: 'Tis a noble widow,
And keeps her reputation pure, and clear
From the least taint of infamy; her life
With the splendour of her actions leaves no tongue
To envy, or detraction. Prithee tell me;
Has she no suitors?

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: Even the best of the shire, Frank,
My lord excepted. Such as sue, and send,
And send, and sue again, but to no purpose.
Their frequent visits have not gained her presence;
Yet she's so far from sullenness, and pride,
That I dare undertake you shall meet from her
A liberal entertainment. I can give you
A catalogue of her suitors names.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: Forbear it,
While I give you good counsel. I am bound to it;
Thy father was my friend, and that affection
I bore to him, in right descends to thee;
Thou art a handsome, and a hopeful youth,
Nor will I have the least affront stick on thee,
If I with any danger can prevent it.

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: I thank your noble care, but pray you in what?
Do I run the hazard?

sp.speaker: Wellborne.
sp.l: Art thou not in love?
Put it not off with wonder.

sp.speaker: Allworth.
sp.l: In love at my years?

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: You think you walk in clouds, but are transrent,
I have heard all, and the choice that you have made;
And with my finger can point out the North star,
By which the loadstone of your folly's guided.
And to confirm this true, what think you of
Fair Margaret the only child, and heir
Of cormorant Overreach? does it blush? and start,
To hear her only named? blush at your want
Of wit, and reason.

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: You are too bitter sir.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: Wounds of this nature are not to be cured
With balms, but corrosives. I must be plain:
Art thou scarce manumised from the porters lodge,
And yet sworn servant to the pantofle,
And dar'st thou dream of marriage? I fear
'Twill be concluded for impossible,
That there is now, nor ere shall be hereafter,
A handsome page, or player's boy of fourteen,
But either loves a wench, or drabs love him;
Court-waiters not exempted.

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: This is madness.
Howe'er you have discovered my intents,
You know my aims are lawful, and if ever
The Queen of flowers, the glory of the spring,
The sweetest comfort to our smell, the rose
Sprang from an envious brier, I may infer
There's such disparity in their conditions,
Between the goddess of my soul, the daughter,
And the base churl her father.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: Grant this true
As I believe it; canst thou ever hope
To enjoy a quiet bed with her, whose father
Ruined thy state?

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: And yours too.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: I confess it.
True I must tell you as a friend, and freely,
That where impossibilities are apparent,
'Tis indiscretion to nourish hopes.
Canst thou imagine, (Let not self-love blind thee)
That sir Giles Overreach, that to make her great
In swelling titles, without touch of conscience,
Will cut his neighbour's throat, and I hope his own too;
Will ere consent to make her thine? Give o'er
And think of some course suitable to thy rank,
And prosper in it.

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: You have well advised me.
But in the mean time, you that are so studious
Of my affairs, wholly neglect your own.
Remember yourself, and in what plight you are.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: No matter, no matter.

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis much material:
You know my fortune, and my means, yet something,
I can spare from myself, to help your wants.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: Nay be not angry. There's eight pieces
To put you in better fashion.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: Money from thee?
From a boy? A stipendiary? one that lives
At the devotion of a stepmother,
And the uncertain favour of a lord?
I'll eat my arms first. Howsoe'er blind fortune
Hath spent the utmost of her malice on me;
Though I am vomited our of an alehouse,
And thus accoutred; know not where to eat,
Or drink, or sleep, but underneath this canopy;
Although I thank thee, I despise thy offer.
And as I in my madness broke my state,
Without th'assistance of another's brain,
In my right wits I'll piece it; at the worst
Die thus, and be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: A strange humour.

div.head: Actus primi, scaena secunda.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: Set all things right, or as my name is order,
And by this staff of office that commands you;
This chain, and double ruff, symbols of power;
Whoever misses in high function,
For one whole week makes forfeiture of his breakfast,
And privilege in the wine-cellar.

sp.speaker: Amble.
sp.l: You are merry
Good master steward.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: Let him; I'll be angry.

sp.speaker: Amble.
sp.l: Why fellow furnace, 'tis not twelve o'clock yet,
Nor dinner taking up, then 'tis allowed
Cooks by their places may be choleric.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: You think you have spoke wisely goodman amble,
My lady's go-before.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: Nay, nay; no wrangling.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: Twit me with the authority of the kitchen?
At all hours, and all places I'll be angry;
And thus provoked, when I am at my prayers,
I will be angry.

sp.speaker: Amble.
sp.l: There was no hurt meant.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: I am friends with thee, and yet I will be angry.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: No matter whom: yet now I think on't
I am angry with my lady.

sp.speaker: Watchall.
sp.l: Heaven forbid, man.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: What cause has she given thee?

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: Cause enough master steward.
I was entertained by her to please her palate,
And till she forswore eating I performed it.
Now since our master, noble Alworth died,
Though I crack my brains to find out tempting sauces.
And raise fortifications in the pastry,
Such as might serve for models in the Low-countries,
Which if they had been practised at Breda,
Spinola might have thrown his cap at it, and never took it.

sp.speaker: Amble.
sp.l: But you had wanted matter there to work on.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: Matter? with fix eggs, and a strike of rye-meal
I had kept the town, till doomsday, perhaps longer.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: But what's this to your pet against my lady?

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: What's this? Marry this, when I am three parts roasted,
And the fourth part parboiled, to prepare her viands,
She keeps her chamber, dines with a panada,
Or water-gruel; my sweat never thought on.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: But your art is seen in the dining-room.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: By whom?
By such as pretend love to her, but come,
To feed upon her. Yet of all the harpies,
That do devour her, I am out of charity
With none so much, as the thin-gutted squire
That's stolen into commission.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: Justice greedy:

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: The same, the same. Meat's cast away upon him,
It never thrives. He holds this paradox,
Who eats not well, can ne'er do justice well:
His stomach's as insatiate as the grave,
Or strumpets ravenous appetites

sp.speaker: Watchall.
sp.l: One knocks.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: Our late young master.

sp.speaker: Amble.
sp.l: Welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: Your hand,
If you have a stomach, a cold bake-meat's ready.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: His father's picture in little.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: We are all your servants.

sp.speaker: Amble.
sp.l: In you he lives.

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: At once, my thanks to all
This is yet some comfort. Is my lady stirring?

div.stage: Enter the lady Alworth, waiting woman, chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: Her presence answer for us.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sort those silks well?
I'll take the air alone.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: You air, and air,
But will you never taste but spoonmeat more?
To what use serve I?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Prithee be not angry,
I shall ere long: i'the mean time, there is gold
To buy thee aprons, and a summer suit.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: I am appeased, and furnace now grows cook.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And as I gave directions, if this morning
I am visited by any, entertain 'em
As heretofore: but say in my excuse
I am indisposed.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: I shall, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Do, and leave me.
Nay stay you Alworth.

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: I shall gladly grow here,
To wait on your commands.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: So soon turned courtier.

sp.speaker: Alworth
sp.l: Stile not that courtship madam, which is duty,
Purchased on your part.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Well, you shall overcome;
I'll not contend in words. How is it with
Your noble master?

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: Ever like himself;
No scruple lessened in the full weight of honour,
He did command me (Pardon my presumption)
As his unworthy deputy to kiss
Your ladyships fair hands.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am honoured in
His favour to me. Does he hold his purpose
For the Low-countreyes?

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: Constantly good madam,
But he will in person first present his service.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And how approve you of his course? you are yet,
Like virgin parchment capable of any
Inscription vicious, or honourable.
I will not force your will, but leave you free
To your own election.

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: Any form, you please,
I will put on: but might I make my choice
With humble emulation I would follow
The path my lord marks to me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis well answered,
And I commend your spirit: you had a father
(Blessed be his memory) that some few hours
Before the will of heaven took him from me,
Who did commend you, by the dearest ties
Of perfect love between us, to my charge:
And therefore what I speak, you are bound to hear
With such respect, as if he lived in me,
He was my husband, and howe'er you are not
Son of my womb, you may be of my love,
Provided you deserve it.

sp.speaker: Allworth.
sp.l: I have found you
(Most honoured madam) the best mother to me,
And with my utmost strengths of care, and service,
Will labour that you never may repent
Your bounties showered upon me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I much hope it.
These were your father's words. If ere my son
Follow the war, tell him it is a school
Where all the principles tending to honour,
Are taught if truly followed: but for such
As repair thither, as a place, in which
They do presume they may with licence practise
Their lusts, and riots, they shall never merit
The noble name of soldiers. To dare boldly
In a fair cause, and for the country's safety
To run upon the cannon's mouth undaunted;
To obey their leaders, and shun mutinies;
To bear, with patience, the winter's cold,
And summer's scorching heat, and not to faint
When plenty of provision fails, with hunger,
Are the essential parts make up a soldier,
Not swearing dice, or drinking.

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: There's no syllable
You speak, but is to me an oracle,
Which but to doubt, were impious.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: To conclude;
Beware ill company, for often men
Are like to those with whom they do converse,
And from one man I warned you, and that's Welborne:
Not cause he's poor, that rather claims your pity,
But that he's in his manners so debauched,
And hath to vicious courses sold himself.
'Tis true your father loved him, while he was
Worthy the loving, but if he had lived
To have seen him as he is, he had cast him off
As you must do.

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: I shall obey in all things.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You follow me to my chamber, you shall have gold
To furnish you like my son, and still supplied,
As I hear from you.

sp.speaker: Alworth.
sp.l: I am still your creature.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Not to be seen?

sp.speaker: Ouerreach.
sp.l: Still cloistered up? Her reason,
I hope assures her, though she make herself
Close prisoner ever for her husband's loss,
'Twill not recover him.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: Sir, it is her will,
Which we that are her servants ought to serve it,
And not dispute. Howe'er , you are nobly welcome,
And if you please to stay, that you may think so;
There came not fix days since from Hull, a pipe
Of rich Canary, which shall spend itself
For my lady's honour.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Is it of the right race?

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: Yes, master greedy.

sp.speaker: Amble.
sp.l: How his mouth runs o'er!

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: I'll make it run, and run. Save your good worship.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Honest master cook, thy hand, again. How I love thee:
Are the good dishes still in being? speak boy.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: If you have a mind to feed, there is a chine
Of beef well seasoned.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Good!

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: A pheasant larded.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: That I might now give thanks for't.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: Other kickshaws.
Besides there came last might from the forest of Sherwood
The fattest stag I ever cooked.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: A stag man?

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: A stag sir part of it prepared for dinner,
And baked in puff-paste.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Puffepast too, sir Giles!
A ponderous chine of beef! A pheasant larded!
And red deer too sir Giles, and baked in puff-paste!
All business set aside; let us give thanks here.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: How the lean skeleton's raped!

sp.speaker: Ouerreach.
sp.l: You know we cannot.

sp.speaker: Marrall.
sp.l: Your worships are to sit on a commission,
And if you fail to come, you lose the cause.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Cause me no causes. I'll prove't, for such a dinner
We may put off a commission: you shall find it
Henrici decimo quarto.

sp.speaker: Ouerreach.
sp.l: Fie master greedy.
Will you lose me a thousand pounds for a dinner?
No more for shame. We must forget the belly,
When we think of profit.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Well, you shall o'errule me
I could e'en cry now. Do you hear master cook.
Send but a corner of that immortal pastry,
And I, in thankfulness, will by your boy
Send you a brace of three-pences.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Will you be so prodigal?

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Remember me to your lady. Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: You know me:

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: I did once, but now I will not,
Thou art no blood of mine. Avant thou beggar,
If ever thou presume to own me more;
I'll have thee caged, and whipped.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: I'll grant the warrant,
Think of pie-corner, furnace.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Will you out sir?
I wonder how you durst creep in.

sp.speaker: Order
sp.l: This is rudeness,
And saucy impudence.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Cannot you stay
To be served among your fellows from the basket,
But you must press in to the hall?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Prithee vanish
Into some outhouse, thought it be the pigsty,
My scullion shall come to thee.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: This is rare:
O here's Tom. Alworth Tom.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: We must be strangers,
Nor would I have you seen here for a million.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Better, and better. He contemns me too?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Foh what a smell's here! what thing's this?

sp.speaker: Chambermaid
sp.l: A creature
Made out of the privy. Let us hence for love's sake,
Or I shall swoon.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: I begin to faint already.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Will know your way?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Or shall we teach it you,
By the head, and shoulders?

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: No: I will not stir.
Do you mark, I will not. Let me see the wretch
That dares attempt to force me. Why you slaves,
Created only to make legs, and cringe;
To carry in a dish, and shift a trencher;
That have not souls only to hope a blessing
Beyond black jacks, or flagons; you that were born
Only to consume meat, and drink, and batten
Upon reversions: who advances? who
Shows me the way?

sp.speaker: Order
sp.l: My lady.

sp.speaker: Chambermaid
sp.l: Here's the monster.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Sweet madam, keep your glove to your nose.

sp.speaker: Chambermaid
sp.l: Or let me,
Fetch some perfumes may be predominant,
You wrong yourself else.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Madam, my designs
Bear me to you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: To me?

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: And though I have met with
But ragged entertainment from your grooms here,
I hope from you to receive that noble usage,
As may become the true friend of your husband,
And then I shall forget these.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am amazed,
To see, and hear this rudeness. Darest thou think
Though sworn, that it can ever find belief,
That I, who to the best men of this country,
Denied my presence since my husband's death,
Can fall so low, as to change words with thee?
Thou son of infamy, forbear my house,
And know, and keep the distance that's between us,
Or, though it be against my gentler temper,
I shall take order you no more shall be
An eyesore to me.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Scorn me not good lady;
But as in form you are angelical
Imitate the heavenly natures, and vouchsafe
At the least awhile to hear me. You will grant
The blood that runs in this arm, is as noble
As that which fills your veins; those costly jewels,
And those rich clothes you wear; your men's observance,
And women's flattery, are in you no virtues,
Nor these rags, with my poverty, in me vices.
You have a fair fame, and I know deserve it,
Yet lady I must say in nothing more,
Than in the pious sorrow you have shown
For your late noble husband.

sp.speaker: Order
sp.l: How she starts!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: And hardly can keep finger from the eye
To hear him named.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Have you ought else to say?

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: That husband madam, was once in his fortune
Almost as low, as I. Want, debts, and quarrels
Lay heavy on him: let it not be thought
A boast in me, though I say, I relieved him.
'Twas I that gave him fashion; mine the sword
That did on all occasions second his;
I brought him on, and off with honour, lady:
And when in all men's judgements he was sunk,
And in his own hopes not to be bunged up,
I stepped unto him, took him by the hand,
And set him upright.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Are not we base rogues
That could forget this?

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: I confess you made him
Master of your estate, nor could your friends
Though he brought no wealth with him, blame you for't.
For he had a shape, and to that shape a mind
Made up of all parts, either great, or noble,
So winning a behaviour, not to be
Resisted, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: 'Tis most true, he had.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: For his sake then, in that I was his friend,
Do not contemn me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: For what's past, excuse me,
I will redeem it. Order give the gentleman
A hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: No madam, on no terms:
I will nor beg, nor borrow six pence of you,
But be supplied elsewhere, or want thus ever.
Only one suit I make, which you deny not
To strangers: and 'tis this.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Fie, nothing else?

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Nothing; unless you please to charge your servants,
To throw away a little respect upon me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: What you demand is yours.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: I thank you, lady.
Now what can be wrought out of such a suit,
Is yet in supposition; I have said all,
When you please you may retire. Nay, all's forgotten,
And for a lucky omen to my project,
Shake hands, and end all quarrels in the cellar.

sp.speaker: Order
sp.l: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Still merry master Welborne.

sp.speaker: Overreach.
sp.l: He's gone I warrant thee; this
Commission crushed him.

sp.speaker: Marrall.
sp.l: Your worship have the way out, and never miss
To squeeze these unthrifts into air: and yet
The chap-fallen justice did his part, returning
For your advantage the certificate
Against his conscience, and his knowledge too,
(With your good favour) to the utter ruin
Of the poor farmer.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: 'Twas for these good ends
I made him a justice. He that bribes his belly,
Is certain to command his soul.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I wonder
(Still with your licence) why, your worship having
The power to put this thin-gut in commission,
You are not in't yourself?

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Thou art a fool;
In being out of office I am out of danger
Where if I were a justice, besides the trouble,
I might, or out of wilfulness, or error,
Run myself finely into a praemunire,
And so become a prey to the informer.
No, I'll have none of't; 'tis enough I keep
Greedy at my devotion: so he serve
My purposes, let him hang, or damn, I care not.
Friendship is but a word.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are all wisdom.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: I would be worldly wise, for the other wisdom
That does prescribe us a well-governed life,
And to do right to others, as ourselves,
I value not an atom.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What course take you
With your good patience to hedge in the manor
Of your neighbour master frugal? as 'tis said,
He will nor sell, nor borrow, nor exchange,
And his land lying in the midst of your many lordships,
Is a foul blemish.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: I have thought on't, Marrall,
And it shall take. I must have all men sellers,
And I the only purchaser.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis most fit sir.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: I'll therefore buy some cottage near his, manor,
Which done, I'll make my men break open his fences;
Ride o'er his standing corn, and in the night
Set fire on his barns; or break his cattles legs.
These trespasses draw on suits, and suits expenses,
Which I can spare, but will soon beggar him.
When I have harried him thus two, or three year,
Though he sue in forma pauperis, in spite
Of all his thrift, and care he'll grow behindhand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The best I ever heard; I could adore you.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Then with the favour of my man of law,
I will pretend some title: want will force him
To put it to arbitrement: then if he sell
For half the value, he shall have ready money,
And I possess his land.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis above wonder!
Welborne was apt to sell, and needed not
These fine arts sir to hook him in.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Well thought on.
This varlet Marrall lives too long, to upbraid me
With my close cheat put upon him. Will nor cold,
Nor hunger kill him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I know not what to think on't.
I have used all means, and the last night I caused
His host the tapster to turn him out of doors;
And have been since with all your friends, and tenants,
And on the forfeit of your favour charged him,
Though a crust of mouldy bread would keep him fró starving
Yet they should not relieve him. This is done, sir.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: That was something, Marrall, but thou must go further,
And suddenly Marrall.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Where, and when you please sir.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: I would have thee seek him out, and if thou canst
Persuade him that 'tis better steal, than beg.
Then if I prove he has but robbed a hen-roost,
Not all the world shall save him from the gallows.
Do any thing to work him to despair,
And 'tis thy masterpiece.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will do my best, sir.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: I am now on my main work with the lord Lovell,
The gallant minded, popular lord Lovell;
The minion of the people's love. I hear
He's come into the country, and my aims are
To insinuate myself into his knowledge,
And then invite him to my house.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have you.
This points at my young mistress.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: She must part with
That humble title, and write honourable,
Right honourable Marrall, my right honourable daughter;
If all I have, or e'er shall get will do it.
I will have her well attended, there are ladies
Of errant knights decayed, and brought so low,
That for cast clothes, and meat, will gladly serve her.
And 'tis my glory, though I come from the city,
To have their issue, whom I have undone,
To kneel to mine, as bondslaves.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis fit state, sir.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: And therefore, I'll not have a chambermaid
That ties her shoes, or any meaner office,
But such whose fathers were right worshipful.
'Tis a rich man's pride, there having ever been
More than a feud, a strange antipathy
Between us, and true gentry.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: See, who's here, sir.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Hence monster; prodigy.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Sir your wife's nephew,
She, and my father tumbled in one belly.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Avoid my sight, thy breath's infectious, rogue.
I shun thee as a leprosy, or the plague.
Come hither Marrall, this is the time to work him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I warrant you, sir.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: By this light I think he's mad.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mad? had you took compassion on yourself,
You long since had been mad.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: You have taken a course
Between you, and my venerable uncle,
To make me so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The more pale spirited you,
That would not be instructed. I swear deeply.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: By what?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By my religion.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Thy religion!
The devil's creed, but what would you have done?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Had there been but one tree in all the shire,
Nor any hope to compass a penny halter,
Before, like you, I had outlived my fortunes,
A with had served my turn to hang myself.
I am zealous in your cause: pray you hang yourself,
And presently, as you love your credit.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Will you stay till you die in a ditch? Or lice devour you?
Or if you dare not do the feat yourself,
But that you'll put the state to charge, and trouble,
Is there no purse to be cut? house to be broken?
Or market women with eggs that you may murder,
And so dispatch the business.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Here's variety
I must confess; but I'll accept of none
Of all your gentle offers, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, have you hope ever to eat again?
Or drink? Or be the master of three farthings?
If you like not hanging, drown yourself, take some course
For your reputation.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: 'Twill not do; dear tempter,
With all the rhetoric the fiend hath taught you.
I am as far as thou art from despair,
Nay, I have confidence, which is more than hope,
To live, and suddenly better than ever.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ha! ha! these castles you build in the air
Will not persuade me, or to give, or lend
A token to you.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: I'll be more kind to thee.
Come thou shalt dine with me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: With you.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Nay more, dine gratis,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Under what hedge I pray you? Or at whose cost?
Are they padders? or abram-men, that are your consorts?

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Thou art incredulous, but thou shalt dine
Not alone at her house, but with a gallant lady,
With me, and with a lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Lady! what lady?
With the lady of the lake, or Queen of fairies?
For I know, it must be an enchanted dinner.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: With the lady Alworth, knave.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, now there's hope
Thy brain is cracked.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Mark there, with what respect
I am entertained.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: With choice no doubt of dogwhips.
Why dost thou ever hope to pass her porter?

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: 'Tis not far off, go with me: trust thine own eyes

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Troth in my hope, or my assurance rather
To see thee curvet, and mount like a dog in a blanket
If ever thou presume to pass her threshold,
I will endure thy company.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Come along then.

div.head: Actus secundi, scaena secunda.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: Could you not command your leisure one hour longer?

sp.speaker: Chambermaid
sp.l: Or half an hour?

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: I have told you what my haste is:
Besides being now another's, not mine own,
Howe'er I much desire to enjoy you longer,
My duty suffers, if to please myself
I should neglect my lord.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Pray you do me the favour
To put these few quince-cakes into your pocket,
They are of mine own preserving.

sp.speaker: Chambermaid
sp.l: And this marmalade;
'Tis comfortable for your stomach,

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: And at parting
Excuse me if I beg a farewell from you.

sp.speaker: Chambermaid
sp.l: You are still before me. I move the same suit
Sir.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: How greedy these chamberers are of a beardless chin!
I thin the titts will ravish him.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: My service
To both.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Ours waits on you.

sp.speaker: Chambermaid
sp.l: And shall do ever.

sp.speaker: Order
sp.l: You are my lady's charge, be therefore careful
That you sustain your parts.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: We can bear I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Here; drink it off, the ingredients are cordial,
And this the true elixir; it hath boiled
Since midnight for you. 'tis the quintessence
Of five cocks of the game, ten dozen of sparrows,
Knuckles of veal, potato roots, and marrow;
Coral, and ambergris: were you two years elder,
And I had a wife, or gamesome mistress
I durst trust you with neither: you need not bait
After this I warrant you; though your journey's long,
You may ride on the strength of this till tomorrow morning.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Your courtesies overwhelm me: I much grieve
To part from such true friends, and yet find comfort;
My attendance on my honourable lord
(Whose resolution holds to visit my lady)
Will speedily bring me back.
sp.stage: Knocking at the gate; Marrall and Welborne within.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Darest thou venture further?

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Yes, yes, and knock again.

sp.speaker: Order
sp.l: 'Tis he; disperse.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Perform it bravely.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: I know my cue, ne'er doubt me.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Beast that I was to make you stay: most welcome,
You were long since expected.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Say so much
To my friend I pray you.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: For your sake I will sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For his sake!

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Mum; this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: More than ever,
I would have believed though I had found it in my primer.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: When I have given you reasons for my late harshness,
You'll pardon, and excuse me: for, believe me
Though now I part abruptly, in my service
I will deserve it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Service! with a vengeance!

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: I am satisfied: farewell Tom.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: All joy stay with you.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: You are happily encountered: I yet never
Presented one so welcome, as I know
You will be to my lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This is some vision;
Or sure these men are mad, to worship a dunghill;
It cannot be a truth.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Be still a pagan,
An unbelieving infidel, be so miscreant,
And meditate on blankets, and on dogwhips.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: I am glad you are come, until I know your pleasure.
I knew not how to serve up my lady's dinner.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: His pleasure; is it possible?

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: What's thy will?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Marry sir, I have some grouse, and turkey chicken,
Some rails, and quails, and my lady willed me ask you
What kind of sauces best affect your palate,
That I may use my utmost skill to please it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The devil's entered this cook, sauce for his palate!
That on my knowledge, for almost this twelvemonth ,
Durst wish but cheeseparings, and brown bread on Sundays.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: That way I like 'em best.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: It shall be done sir.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: What think you of the hedge we shall dine under?
Shall we feed gratis?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I know not what to think;
Pray you make me not mad.

sp.speaker: Order
sp.l: This place becomes you not;
Pray you walk sir, to the dining room.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: I am well here
Till her ladyship quits her chamber.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well here say you?
'Tis a rare change! but yesterday you thought
Yourself well in a barn, wrapped up in peas-straw.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: O sir, you are wished for.

sp.speaker: Chambermaid
sp.l: My lady dreamt sir of you.

sp.speaker: Vvom.
sp.l: And the first command she gave, after she rose
Was (Her devotions done) to give her notice
When you approached here.

sp.speaker: Chambermaid
sp.l: Which is done on my virtue.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall be converted, I begin to grow
Into a new belief, which saints, nor angels
Could have won me to have faith in.

sp.speaker: Vvom.
sp.l: Sir, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I come to meet you, and languished till I saw you.
This first kiss is for form; I allow a second
To such a friend.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To such a friend! Heaven bless me!

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: I am wholly yours, yet madam, if you please
To grace this gentleman with a salute.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Salute me at his bidding.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: I shall receive it
As a most high favour.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, you may command me.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Run backward from a lady? and such a lady?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To kiss her foot is too poor, me a favour;
I am unworthy of

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Nay, pray you rise,
And since you are so humble, I'll exalt you
You shall dine with me today, at mine own table.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your ladyship's table? I am not good enough
To sit at your steward's board.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You are too modest:
I will not be denied.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Will you still be babbling;
Till your meat freeze on the table? the old trick still.
My art never thought on.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Your arm, master Welborne:
Nay keep us company.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I was never so graced.

div.stage: Exeunt Welborne. Lady. Amble. Marrall. woman.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: So we have played our parts, and are come off well.
But if I know the mystery why my lady
Consented to it, or why master Welborne
Desired it, may I perish.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Would I had
The roasting of his heart, that cheated him,
And forces the poor gentleman to these shifts,
By fire (For cooks are Persians, and swear by it).
Of all the griping, and extorting tyrants
I ever heard, or read of, I never met
A match to sir Giles Overreach.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: What will you take
To tell him so fellow furnace?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Just as much
As my throat is worth, for that would be the price on't.
To have a usurer that starves himself,
And wears a cloak of one and twenty years
On a suit of fourteen groats, bought of the hangman,
To grow rich, and then purchase, is too common:
But this sir Giles feeds high, keeps many servants,
Who must at his command do any outrage;
Rich in his habit; vast in his expenses;
Yet he to admiration still increases
In wealth, and lordships.

sp.speaker: Order
sp.l: He frights men out of their estates,
And breaks through all law-netts, made to curb ill men,
As they were cobwebs. No man dares reprove him.
Such a spirit to dare, and power to do, were never
Lodged so unluckily.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Ha, ha; I shall burst.

sp.speaker: Order
sp.l: Contain thyself man.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Or make us partakers
Of your sudden mirth.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Ha, ha, my lady has got
Such a guest at her table, this term-driver Marrall,
This swipe of an attorney.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: What of him man?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: The knave thinks still he's at the cook's shop in Ram-alley,
Where the clerks divide, and the elder is to choose;
And feeds so slovenly.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: My lady
Drank to him for fashion's sake, or to please master Welborne.
As I live he rises, and takes up a dish,
In which there were some remnants of a boiled capon,
And pledges her in white-broth.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis like,
The rest of his tribe.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: And when I brought him wine,
He leaves his stool, and after a leg or two
Most humbly thanks my worship.

sp.speaker: Order
sp.l: Rose already.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: I shall be chid.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: My lady frowns.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You wait well.
Let me have no more of this, I observed your icering.
Sirrah, I'll have you know, whom I think worthy
To sit at my table, be he never so mean,
When I am present, is not your companion.

sp.speaker: Order
sp.l: Nay she'll preserve what's due to her.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: This refreshing
Follows your flux of laughter.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You are master.
Of your own will. I know so much of manners
As not to inquire your purposes, in a word
To me you are ever welcome, as to a house
That is your own.

sp.speaker: Velb.
sp.l: Mark that.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: With reverence sir,
And it like your worship.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Trouble yourself no farther;
Dear madam; my heart's full of zeal, and service,
However in my language I am sparing.
Come master Marrall.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I attend your worship.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I see in your looks you are sorry, and you know me
An easy mistress: be merry; I have forgotten all.
Order, and furnace come with me, I must give you
Further directions.

sp.speaker: Order
sp.l: What you please.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: We are ready.

sp.speaker: Welborne.
sp.l: I think I am in a good way.

sp.speaker: Marrall.
sp.l: Good sir; the best way.
The certain best way.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: There are casualties
That men are subject too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are above 'em,
And as you are already worshipful,
I hope ere long you will increase in worship,
And be right worshipful.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Prithee do not flout me.
What I shall be, I shall be. Is't for your ease,
You keep your hat off?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ease, and it like your worship?
I hope Jack Marrall shall not live so long,
To prove himself such an unmannerly beast,
Though it hail hazel nuts, as to be covered
When your worship's present.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Is not this a true rogue?Aside.
That out of mere hope of a future cozenage
Can turn thus suddenly: 'tis rank already.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I know your worship's wise, and needs no counsel:
Yet if in my desire to do you service,
I humbly offer my advice, (But still
Under correction) I hope I shall not
Incur your high displeasure.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: No; speak freely.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then in my judgement sir, my simple judgement,
(Still with your Whorship's favour) I could wish you
A better habit, for this cannot be,
But much distasteful to the noble lady.
(I say no more) that loves you, for this morning
To me (And I am but a swine to her)
Before th'assurance of her wealth perfumed you;
You savoured not of amber.

sp.speaker: Vvelb,
sp.l: I do now then?
sp.stage: Kisses the end of his cudgel,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This your battoon hath got a touch of it.
Yet if you please for change I have twenty pounds here
Which, out of my true love I presently
Lay down at your Whorship's feet: 'twill serve to buy you
A riding suit.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: But where's the horse?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My gelding
Is at your service: nay, you shall ride me
Before your worship shall be put to the trouble
To walk a foot. Alas, when you are lord
Of this lady's manor (As I know you will be)
You may with the lease of glebe land, called Knaves-acre,
A place I would manure, requite your vassal.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: I thank thy love: but must make no use of it,
What's twenty pounds?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis all that I can make, sir.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Dost thou think though I want clothes I could not have 'em,
For one word to my lady?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As I know not that.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Come I'll tell thee a secret, and so leave thee.
I'll not give her the advantage, though she be
A gallant minded lady, after we are married
(There being no woman, but is sometimes froward)
To hit me in the teeth, and say she was forced
To buy my wedding clothes, and took me on
With a plain riding-suit, and an ambling nag.
No, I'll be furnished something like myself.
And so farewell; for thy suit touching knave's acre.
When it is mine 'tis thine.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I thank your worship. Exit Welb.
How was cozened in the calculation
Of this man's fortune, my master cozened too
Whose pupil I am in the art of undoing men,
For that is our profession; well, well, master Welborne
You are of a sweet nature, and fit again to be cheated:
Which, if the fates please, when you are possessed
Of the land, and lady, you sans question shall be.
I'll presently think of the means.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Sirrah, take my horse.
I'll walk to get me an appetite? 'tis but a mile,
And exercise will keep me, from being pursy.
Ha! Marrall! is he conjuring! perhaps
The knave has wrought the prodigal to do
Some outrage on himself, and now he feels
Compunction in his conscience for't: no matter
So it be done, Marrall.

sp.speaker: Marrall.
sp.l: Sir,

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: How succeed we
In our plot on Welborne?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Never better sir.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Has he hanged, or drowned himself?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No sir, he lives.
Lives once more to be made a prey to you,
A greater prey than ever.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Art thou in thy wits?
If thou art reveal this miracle, and briefly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A lady sir, is fallen in love with him.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: With him? what lady?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The rich lady Alworth.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Thou dolt; how dar'st thou speak this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I speak truth;
And I do so but once a year, unless
It be to you sir, we dined with her ladyship,
I thank his worship.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: His worship!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As I live sir;
I dined with him, at the great lady's table,
Simple as I stand here, and saw when, she kissed him,
And would at his request, have kissed me too,
But I was not so audacious, as some youths are,
And dare do any thing be it never so absurd,
And sad after performance.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Why thou rascal,
To tell me these impossibilities:
Dine, at her table? and kiss him? or thee?
Impudent varlet. Have not I myself
To whom great countess's doors have oft flew open,
Ten times attempted, since her husband's death
In vain to see her, though I came --- a suitor;
And yet your good solicitor-ship, and rogue ---- Welborne,
Were brought into her presence, feasted with her.
But that I know thee a dog, that cannot blush
This most incredible lie would call up one
On thy buttermilk cheeks.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Shall I not trust my eyes sir?
Or taste? I feel her good cheer in my belly.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: You shall feel me, if you give not over sirrah,
Recover your brains again, and be no more gulled
With a beggar's plot assisted by the aides
Of serving men, and chambermaids; for beyond these
Thou never sawest a woman, or I'll quit you
From my employments.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Will you credit this yet?
On my confidence of their marriage I offered Welborne
(I would give a crown now, I durst say his worship) --- aside
My nag, and twenty pounds.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Did you so I do? Strikes him down
Was this the way to work him to despair
Or rather to cross me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Will your worship kill me?

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: No, no; but drive the lying spirit out of you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He's gone.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: I have done then: now forgetting,
Your late imaginary feast, and lady.
Know my lord Lovell dines with me tomorrow,
Be careful naught, be wanting to receive him,
And bid my daughter's women trim her up,
Though they paint her, so she catch the lord, I'll thank 'em,
There's a piece for my late blows.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I must yet suffer:
But there may be a time. ---- aside.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Do you grumble?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Louell.
sp.l: Walk the horses down the hill: something in private,
I must impart to Alworth.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: O my lord,
What sacrifice of reverence, duty watching;
Although I could put off the use of sleep,
And ever wait on your commands serve 'em;
What dangers, though in never so horrid shapes,
Nay death itself, though I should run to meet it,
Can I, and with a thankful willingness suffer;
But still the retribution will fall short
Of your bounties showered upon me.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Loving youth;
Till what I purpose be put into act,
Do not o'erprize it, since you have trusted me
With your souls nearest, nay her dearest secret,
Rest confident 'tis in a cabinet locked,
Treachery shall never open, I have found you
(For so much to your face I must profess,
How ere you guard your modesty with a blush for't)
More zealous in your love, and service to me
Than I have been in my rewards.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Still great ones
Above my merit.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Such your gratitude calls 'em:
Nor am I of that harsh, and rugged temper
As some great men are taxed, with who imagine
They part from the respect due to their honours,
If they use not all such as follow 'em,
Without distinction of their births, like slaves.
I am not so conditioned: I can make
A fitting difference between my footboy,
And a gentleman, by want compelled to serve me.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: 'Tis thankfully acknowledged: you have been
More like a father to me than a master.
Pray you pardon the comparison.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I allow it;
And to give you assurance I am pleased in't,
My carriage and demeanour to your mistress
Fair Margaret, shall truly witness for me
I can command my passions.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: 'Tis a conquest
Few lords can boast of when they are tempted. Oh!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Why do you sigh? can you be doubtful of me?
By that fair name, I in the wars have purchased,
And all my actions hitherto untainted,
I will not be more true to mine own honour,
Than to my Alworth.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: As you are the brave lord Lovell,
Your bare word only given, is an assurance
Of more validity, and weight to me
Than all the oaths bound up with imprecations,
Which when they would deceive, most courtiers practice:
Yet being a man (For sure to style you more
Would relish of gross flattery) I am forced
Against my confidence of your worth, and virtues,
To doubt, nay more to fear.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: So young, and jealous?

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Were you to encounter with a single foe,
The victory were certain: but to stand
The charge of two such potent enemies,
At once assaulting you, as wealth and beauty,
And those too seconded with power, is odds
Too great for Hercules.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Speak your doubts, and fears,
Since you will nourish 'em in plainer language,
That I may understand 'em.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: What's your will;
Though I lend arms against my self, (Provided
They may advantage you) must be obeyed.
My much loved lord, were Margaret only fair,
The cannon of her more than earthly form,
Though mounted high, commanding all beneath it,
And rammed with bullets of her sparkling eyes,
Of all the bulwarks that defend your senses
Could batter more, but that which guards your sight.
But when the well tuned accents of her tongue
Make music to you, and with numerous sounds
Assault your hearing (Such as if Ulysses
Now lived again, howe'er he stood the Sirens,
Could not resist) the combat must grow doubtful,
Between your reason, and rebellious passions.
Add this too; when you feel her touch, and breath,
Like a soft western wind, when it glides o'er
Arabia, creating gums, and spices:
And in the van, the nectar of her lips
Which you must taste, bring the battalions on,
Well armed, and strongly lived with her discourse,
And knowing manners, to give entertainment,
Hippolytus himself would leave Diana,
To follow such a Venus.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Love hath made you
Poetical, Alworth.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Grant all these beat off,
Which if it be in man to do, you'll do it;
Mammon in sir Giles Overreach steps in
With heaps of ill got gold, and so much land,
To make her more remarkable, as would tire
A falcon's wings in one day to fly over.
O my good lord, these powerful aids, which would
Make a mishapen negro beautiful,
(Yet are but ornaments to give her lustre,
That in herself is all perfection) must
Prevail for her. I here release your trust.
'Tis happiness, enough, for me to serve you,
And sometimes with chaste eyes to look upon her.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Why shall I swear?

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: O by no means my lord;
And wrong not so your judgement to the world
As from your fond indulgence to a boy,
Your page, your servant, to refuse a blessing
Divers great men are rivals for.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Suspend
Your judgement till the trial. How far is it
'T Overreach house?

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: At the most some half hours riding;
You'll soon be there.

sp.speaker: Eou.
sp.l: And you the sooner freed
From your jealous fears.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: O that I durst but hope it.

sp.speaker: Overreach
sp.l: Spare for no cost, let my dressers crack with the weight
Of curious viands.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Store indeed's no sore, sir.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: That proverb fits your stomach
Master greedy.
And let no plate be seen, but what's pure gold,
Or such whose workmanship exceeds the matter
That it is made of, let my choicest linen
Perfume the room, and when we wash the water
With precious powders mixed, so please my lord,
That he may with envy wish to bathe soever .

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Twil be very chargeable.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Avant you drudge:
Now all my laboured ends are at the stake,
Is't a time to think of thrift? call in my daughter,
And master. Justice, since you love choice dishes,
And plenty of 'em.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: As I do indeed sir,
Almost as much as to give thanks for 'em.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: I do confer that providence, with my power
Of absolute command to have abundance,
To your best care.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: I'll punctually discharge it
And give the best directions. Now am I
In mine own conceit a monarch, at the least
Arch-president of the boiled, the roast, the baked,
For which I will eat often, and give thanks,
When my bellies braced up like a drum, and that's pure justice.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: I must be so: should the foolish girl prove modest. Exit greedie.
She may spoil all, she had it not from me,
But from her mother, I was ever forward,
As she must be, and therefore I'll prepare her.
Alone, and let your women wait without. Margaret.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Your pleasure sir?

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Ha, this is a neat dressing!
These orient pearls, and diamonds well placed too!
The gown affects me not, it should have been
Embroidered o'er, and o'er with flowers of gold,
But these rich jewels, and quaint fashion help it.
And how below? since oft the wanton eye
The face observed, descends unto the foot;
Which being well proportioned, as yours is,
Invites as much as perfect white, and red,
Though without art, how like you, your new woman
The lady Downefalne?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Well for a companion;
Not as a servant.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Is she humble Meg?
And careful too; her ladyship forgotten?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I pity her fortune.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Pity her? Trample on her.
I took her up in an old tamin gown,
(Even starved for want of two penny chops) to serve thee:
And if I understand, she but repines
To do thee any duty, though never so servile,
I'll pack her to her knight, where I have lodged him,
Into the counter, and there let 'em howl together.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You know your own ways, but for me I blush
When I command her, that was once attended
With persons, not inferior to myself
In birth.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: In birth? Why art thou not my daughter?
The blessed child of my industry, and wealth?
Why foolish girl, was't not to make thee great,
That I have run, and still pursue those ways
That hale down curses on me, which I mind not,
Part with these humble thoughts, and apt thyself
To the noble state I labour to advance thee,
Or by my hopes to see thee honourable,
I will adopt a stranger to my heir,
And throw thee from my care, do not provoke me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I will not sir; mould me which way you please.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: How interrupted?

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: 'Tis matter of importance.
The cook sir is self-willed and will not learn
From my experience, there's a fawn borough in sir,
And for my life I cannot make him roast it,
With a Norfolk dumpling in the belly of it.
And sir, we wise-men know, without the dumpling
'Tis not worth three pence,

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Would it were whole in thy belly
To stuff it out; cook it any way, prithee leave me

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: Without order for the dumpling?

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Let it be dumpled
Which way thou wilt, or tell him I will scald him
In his own cauldron.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: I had lost my stomach,
Had I lost my mistress dumpling, I'll give thanks for.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: But to our business Meg, you have heard who dines here?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I have sir.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: 'Tis an honourable man,
A lord, Megge, and commands a regiment
Of soldiers, and what's rare is one himself;
A bold, and understanding one; and to be
A lord, and a good leader in one volume,
Is granted unto few, but such as rise up
The kingdom's glory.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: I'll resign my office,
If I be not better obeyed.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: 'Slight, art thou frantic?

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: Frantic 'twould make me a frantic, and stark-mad,
Were I not a justice of peace, and coram too,
Which this rebellious cook cares not a straw for.
There are a dozen of woodcocks.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Make thyself
Thirteen, the bakers dozen.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: I am contented
So they may be dressed to my mind, he has found out
A new device for sauce, and will not dish 'em
With toasts, and butter, my father was a tailor,
And my name though a justice, greedy woodcock,
And ere I'll see my lineage so abused,
I'll give up my commission.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Cooke, rogue obey him.
I have given the word, pray you now remove yourself,
To a collar of brawn, and trouble me no farther.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: I will, and meditate what to eat at dinner.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: And as I said Meg, when this gull disturbed us;
This honourable lord, this colonel
I would have thy husband.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There's too much disparity
Between his quality, and mine to hope it.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: I more than hope't, and doubt not to effect it,
Be thou no enemy to thyself, my wealth
Shall weigh his titles down, and make you equals.
Now for the means to assure him thine; observe me;
Remember he's a courtier, and a soldier
And not to be trifled with, and therefore when
He comes to woe you, see you, do not coy it.
This mincing modesty hath spoiled many a match
By a first refusal, in vain after hoped for.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You'll have me sir, preserve the distance, that
Confines a virgin?

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Virgin me no virgins.
I must have you lose that name, or you lose me,
I will have you private, start not, I say private,
If thou art my true daughter, not a bastard
Thou wilt venture alone with one man, though he came
Like Jupiter to Semele, and come off too.
And therefore when he kisses you, kiss close.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I have heard this is the strumpets fashion sir,
Which I must never learn.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Learn any thing,
And from any creature that may make thee great;
From the devil himself.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: This is but devilish doctrine.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Or if his blood grow hot, suppose he offer
Beyond this, do not you stay till it cool,
But meet his ardour, if a couch be near,
Sit down on't, and invite him.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: In your house?
Your own house sir, for heaven's sake, what are you then?
Or what shall I be sir?

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Stand not on form,
Words are no substances.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Though you could dispense
With your own honour; cast aside religion,
The hopes of heaven, or fear of hell; excuse me
In worldly policy, this is not the way
To make me his wife, his whore I grant it may do.
My maiden honour so soon yielded up,
Nay prostituted, cannot but assure him
I that am light to him will not hold weight
When he is tempted by others: so in judgement
When to his lust I have given up my honour
He must, and will forsake me,

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: How? forsake thee?
Do I wear a sword for fashion? or is this arm
Shrunk up? or withered? does there live a man
Of that large list I have encountered with.
Can truly say I e'er gave inch of ground,
Not purchased with his blood, that did oppose me?
Forsake thee when the thing is done? he dares not.
Give me but proof, he has enjoyed thy person,
Though all his captains, echoes to his will,
Stood armed by his side to justify the wrong,
And he himself in the head of his bold troop,
Spite of his lordship, and his colonelship,
Or the judge's favour, I will make him render
A bloody and a strict account, and force him
By marrying thee, to cure thy wounded honour;
I have said it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, the man of honours come
Newly alighted.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: In; without reply
And do as I command, or thou art lost. Exit Marg.
Is the loud music I gave order for
Ready to receive him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis sir.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Let 'em sound
A princely welcome, roughness a while leave me,
For fawning now, a stranger to my nature
Must make way for me.
sp.stage: Loud music. Enter Lovell. Greed. Alw. Mar.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Sir, you meet your trouble.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: What you are pleased to style so is an honour
Above my worth, and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Strange, so humble.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: A justice of peace my lord. Presents greedy to him.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Your hand good sir.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: This is a lord; and some think this a favour;
But I had rather have my hand in my dumpling.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Room for my lord.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I miss sir your fair daughter,
To crown my welcome.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: May it please my lord
To taste a glass of Greek wine first, and suddenly
She shall attend my lord.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: You'll be obeyed sir.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: 'Tis to my wish; as soon as come ask for her!
Why, Meg? Megge Overreach. how! tears in your eyes!
Ha! dry 'em quickly, or I'll dig 'em out.
Is this a time to whimper? meet that greatness
That flies into thy bosom, think what 'tis
For me to say, my honourable daughter.
And thou, when I stand bare, to say put on,
Or father you forget yourself, no more,
But be instructed, or expect, he comes.
A black-browed girl my lord,
sp.stage: Enter Lovell. Greedie Alworth. Marrall. they salute.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: As I live a rare one.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: He's took already: I am lost.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: That kiss,
Came twanging off I like it, quit the room:The rest off.
A little bashful my good lord, but you
I hope will teach her boldness.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I am happy
In such a scholar: but.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: I am past learning.
And therefore leave you to yourselves: remember ---To his daughter.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: You see fair lady, your father is solicitous.
To have you change the barren name of virgin
Into a hopeful wife.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: He haste my lord,
Holds no power o'er my will.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But o'er your duty.

sp.speaker: Marg,
sp.l: Which forced too much may break.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Bend rather sweetest:
Think of your years.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Too few to match with yours:
And choicest fruits too soon plucked, rot, and wither.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Do you think I am old?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I am sure I am too young.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I can advance you.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: To a hill of sorrow,
Where every hour I may expect to fall,
But never hope firm footing. You are noble,
I of a low descent, however rich;
And tissues matched with scarlet suit but ill.
O my good lord I could say more, but that
I dare not trust these walls.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Pray you trust my ear then.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Close at it! whispering! this is excellent!
And by their postures, a consent on both parts.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: Sir Giles, sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: The great fiend stop that clapper.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: It must ring out sir, when my belly rings noon
The backed meats are run out, the roast turned powder.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: I shall powder you.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: Beat me to dust I care not.
In such a cause as this, I'll die a martyr.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Marry and shall: you barathrum of the shambles. Strikes him.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: How! strike a justice of peace? 'tis pett treason.
Edwardi quinto, but that you are my friend
I could commit you without bail, or mainprize.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Leave your balling sir, or I shall commit you;
Where you shall not dine today, disturb my lord,
When he is in discourse?

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: Is't a time to talk
When we should be munching?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Ha! I heard some noise.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Mum, villain, vanish: shall we break a bargain
Almost made up. Thrust greedie off.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Lady, I understand you;
And rest most happy in your choice, believe it,
I'll be a careful pilot to direct
Your yet uncertain bark to a port of safety.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: So shall your honour save two lives, and bind us
Your slaves for ever.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I am in the act rewarded,
Since it is good, howe'er you must put on
And amorous carriage towards me, to delude
Your subtle father.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I am proof to that.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Now break we off our conference. Sir Giles.
Where is sir Giles?

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: My noble lord; and how
Does your lordship find her?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Apt sir Giles, and coming,
And I like her the better.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: So do I too.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Yet should we take forts at the first assault
'Twere poor in the defendant, I must confirm her
With a love letter or two, which I must have
Delivered by my page, and you give way to't.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: With all my soul, a towardly gentleman,
Your hand good master Alworth, know my house
Is ever open to you.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: 'Twas shut till now.Aside.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Well done, well done, my honourable daughter:
Thou'rt so already: know this gentle youth,
And cherish him my honourable daughter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall with my best care. Noise within as of a coach.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: A coach.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: More stops
Before we go to dinner! O my guts!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: If I find welcome
You share in it; if not I'll back again,
Now I know your ends, for I come armed for all
Can be objected.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: How! the lady Alworth!

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: And thus attended!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, I am a dolt;Lovell salutes the lady, the lady salutes Margaret.
The spirit of lies had entered me.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Peace patch,
'Tis more than wonder! an astonishment
That does possess me wholly!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Noble lady,
This is a favour to prevent my visit,
The service of my life can never equal.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: My lord, I laid wait for you, and much hoped
You would have made my poor house your first inn:
And therefore doubting that you might forget me,
Or too long dwell here having such ample cause
In this unequalled beauty for your stay;
And fearing to trust any but myself
With the relation of my service to you,
I borrowed so much from my long restraint,
And took the air in person to invite you.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Your bounties are so great they rob me, madam
Of words to give you thanks.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Good sir Giles Overreach. Salutes him.
How dost thou Marrall? liked you my meat so ill,
You'll dine no more with me?

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: I will when you please
And it like your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: When you please master greedy
If meat can do it, you shall be satisfied,
And now my lord, pray take into your knowledge
This gentleman, howe'er his outside's course. Presents Welborne.
His inward linings are as fine, and fair,
As any man's: wonder not I speak at large:
And howsoe'er his humour carries him
To be thus accoutred; or what taint soever
For his wild life hath stuck upon his fame,
He may erelong, with boldness rank himself
With some that have contemned him. Sir Giles Overreach
If I am welcome bid him so.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: My nephew.
He has been too long a stranger: faith you have:
Pray let it be mended,Lovell conferring with Welborne.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why sir, what do you mean?
This is rogue Welborne, monster, prodigy.
That should hang, or drown himself, no man of worship,
Much less your nephew;

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Well sirrah, we shall reckon
For this here after.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll not lose my jeer
Though I be beaten dead for't.

sp.speaker: Welb.
sp.l: Let my silence plead
In my excuse my lord till better leisure
Offer itself to hear a full relation
Of my poor fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I would hear, and help 'em.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Your dinner waits you.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Pray you lead, we follow.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Nay you are my guest, come dear master Welborne.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: Dear master Welborne! So she said; heaven! heaven!
If my belly would give me leave I could ruminate
All day on this: I have granted twenty warrants.
To have him committed from all prisons in the shire,
To Nottingham jail; and now dear master Welborne!
And my good nephew, but I play the fool
To stand here prating, and forget my dinner.
Are they set Marrall?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Long since, pray you a word sir.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: No wording now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In troth, I must; my master
Knowing you are his good friend, makes bold with you,
And does entreat you, more guests being come in,
Than he expected, especially his nephew,
The table being full too, you would excuse him
And sup with him on the cold meat.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: How! no dinner
After all my care?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis but a penance for
A meal; besides, you broke your fast.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: That was
But a bit to stay my stomach: a man in commission
Give place to a tatterdemalion?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No bug words sir,
Should his worship hear you?

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: Lose my dumpling too?
And buttered toasts, and woodcocks?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, have patience.
If you will dispense a little with your worship,
And sit with the waiting women, you have dumpling,
Woodcock, and buttered costs too.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.l: This revives me
I will gorge there sufficiently.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This is the way sir.

sp.speaker: Overreach
sp.l: She's caught! O women! she neglects my lord,
And all her compliments applied to Welborne!
The garments of her widowhood laid by,
She now appears as glorious as the spring,
Her eyes fixed on him; in the wine she drinks,
He being her pledge; she sends him burning kisses,
And sits on thorns, till she be private with him.
She leaves my meat to feed upon his looks;
And if in our discourse he be but named
From her a deep sigh follows, but why grieve I
At this? it makes for me, if she prove his
All that is hers is mine, as I will work him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir the whole board is troubled at your rising.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: No matter, I'll excuse it, prithee Marrall,
Watch an occasion to invite my nephew
To speak with me in private.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who? the rogue,
The lady scorned to look on?

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: You are a wag

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: See sir she's come, and cannot be without him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: With your favour sir, after a plenteous dinner,
I shall make bold to walk, a turn, or two
In your rare garden.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: There's an arbour too
If your ladyship please to use it

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Come master Welborne.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: Grosser, and grosser, now I believe the poet
Feigned not but was historical, when he wrote.
Pasiphae was enamoured of a bull,
This lady's lust's more monstrous. My good lord,
Excuse my manners.
sp.stage: Enter Lovell, Margaret and the rest

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: There needs none sir Giles,
I may ere long say father, when it pleases
My dearest mistress to give warrant to it.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: She shall seal to it my lord, and make me happy.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: My lady is returned.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Provide my coach,
I'll instantly away: my thanks sir Giles
For my entertainment.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
sp.l: 'Tis your nobleness
To think it such.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I must do you a further wrong
In taking away your honourable guest.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I wait on you madam, farewell good sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Good mistress Margaret: nay come master Welborne,
I must not leave you behind, in sooth I must not.

sp.speaker: Ouer.
